response.answer_text: For those who like to plunge into the past and love historical movies, I have collected the top historical dramas in my opinion, which will make you think about a lot. There Will Be Blood The film, which is based on Upton Sinclair's novel, tells the story of the American entrepreneur Daniel Plainview, whose thirst for success led to self-destruction and fall into the abyss of madness. Daniel Day-Lewis, as always, throws an incredible performance in the movie. Frost/Nixon Three years after his forced resignation, former US President Nixon decides to give the popular journalist and showman Frost an exclusive interview, which turns into a real political duel in which both are ready for anything to win. The Flowers of War In the midst of the Sino-Japanese War, American John arrives in Nanjing and is locked up in a church with the students of the local monastery and the girls from the brothel, for whose lives he is now responsible. The Physician A beautiful and multifaceted movie about a boy who, dreaming of saving humanity from suffering, has come a long way and made discoveries that have changed the lives of many people. Hotel Rwanda The film depicts a real story of Kenyan hotel manager Paul Rusesabagina, who during the civil war saved more than 1,000 refugees from genocide, risking his own life. Don Cheadle, in my opinion, was one of the main reasons film succeeded, but the plot was very nice as well.  Marie Antoinette The 14-year-old daughter of the Empress of Austria Maria Theresa marries Louis XVI and traditionally leaves everything that would remind her of a foreign court to start a new life for the French queen. The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford Having joined the gang of a living legend and daring raider Jesse James, young Robert Ford understands that his idol is not a hero at all, but an unprincipled and cruel sadist, who will not be easy to survive next to. The Last Samurai In the 70s of the XIX century, the Japanese emperor decided on a global modernization, within the framework of which he intends to exterminate samurai warriors and train the army in the modern art of warfare. To do this, he hires an American officer, Nathan Algren, whom the Land of the Rising Sun will change forever. Kingdom of Heaven The script of the film is based on the loosely presented events that preceded the Third Crusade of 1189-1192: the war between the Kingdom of Jerusalem and the Ayyubids and the siege of Jerusalem by Saladin. The Last King of Scotland After graduating from college, a young Scottish doctor Nicholas comes to work in Uganda, where, by the will of circumstances, he becomes the president's personal doctor, and eventually turns into one of the closest advisers to the head of state. When Nicholas realizes that he has become an accomplice of the bloody terror, he decides to flee the country. Gangs of New York The history of New York, which, like any other city, was born by the people living in it. At the centre of the conflict are two criminal groups - the Irish and the Native Americans, ready to go all the way in the struggle for territory. The King's Speech Stuttering since childhood, the Duke of York is horrified by the news that he should become king and personify the hope, face and voice of the British people. Australian specialist Lionel Logue, who practices controversial but effective methods, agrees to help him. Colin Firth who is staring in the leading role won Academy Award for best actor in 2011 and it was truly deserved.

Hey there everyone! Hope you all are doing well. Just to make things clear, I am not going to compile a list here and will come straight to the point by making the question more specific. Which is the best historical movie, ever made? Note: By the end of this post you would have got the answers for the below questions. Significance of the Girl in Red Coat in the movie.Who are the Schindlerjuden?Is the movie historically accurate?Which is Stephen Spielberg best work?The choice was very obvious for me - Schindler's List by Steven Spielberg.  The Girl in the Red Coat - Image Copyright BuzzFeed. Synopsis: This movie is based on a true story and stars Liam Neeson as Oskar Schindler, a German businessman in Poland who sees an opportunity to make money from the Nazis' rise to power during the 2nd World War. He starts a company to make cookware and utensils, using flattery and bribes to win military contracts, and brings in accountant and financier Itzhak Stern (Ben Kingsley) to help run the factory. By staffing his plant with Jews who've been herded into Krakow's ghetto by Nazi troops, Schindler has a dependable unpaid labor force. For Stern, a job in a war-related plant could mean survival for himself and the other Jews working for Schindler. However, in 1942, all of Krakow's Jews are assigned to the Plaszow Forced Labor Camp, overseen by Commandant Amon Goeth (Ralph Fiennes), an embittered alcoholic who occasionally shoots prisoners from his balcony. Schindler arranges to continue using Polish Jews in his plant, but, as he sees what is happening to his employees, he begins to develop a conscience. He realizes that his factory (now refitted to manufacture ammunition) is the only thing preventing his staff from being shipped to the death camps. Soon Schindler demands more workers and starts bribing Nazi leaders to keep Jews on his employee lists and out of the camps.  Link to get the book from Amazon[1] . Schindler's List was nominated for 12 Academy Awards and won seven, including Best Picture and a long-coveted Best Director for Spielberg, and it quickly gained praise as one of the finest American movies about the Holocaust. Having watched countless Holocaust themed movies in the last few years like Quentin Tarantino's ‘Inglorious Basterds', Roman Polanski's ‘The Pianist', Robert Benigni's ‘Life is Beautiful’ and very recently Taika Waititis's ‘Jojo Rabbit', Schindler's List is the most significant movie to be ever made due to the fact that by the time Germany fell to the allies, Schindler had lost his entire fortune and saved 1,100 + people from likely death. These people came to be known as the Schindlerjuden (Schindler's Jews).  Oskar Schindler 2nd from right with Schindlerjuden - Image Copyright Google. There is a scene from the movie that will bring you to tears: Oskar Schindler: I could have got more. I could have got more, I don't know. If I just...I could have got more. Itzhak Stern: Oskar, there are 1,100 people who are alive because of you. Look at them. Oskar Schindler: If I had made more money. I threw away so much money. (laughs, then gets teary-eyed) You have no idea. If I just... Itzhak Stern: There will be generations because of you. Oskar Schindler: I didn't do enough. Itzhak Stern: You did so much. Oskar Schindler: This car. Goeth would have bought this car. Why did I keep the car? Ten people right there. Ten people. Ten more people. This pin..two people. This is gold. Two people. He would have given me two more, at least one. One more person. A person, Stern, for this. (starts crying) I could have got one more person, and I didn't! I -- I -- I -- I didn't!    Trivia: Steven Spielberg offered the job of director to Roman Polanski. Polanski turned it down because the subject was too personal. He had lived in the Krakow ghetto until the age of eight, when he escaped on the day of the liquidation. His mother later died at the Auschwitz concentration camp. After learning this, Spielberg immediately and repeatedly apologized for bringing up such a traumatic memory. However, Polanski would later direct his own movie about the Holocaust which contained many autobiographical elements, The Pianist (2002). Seven lists in all were made by Oskar Schindler and his associates during the war, while four are known to still exist. Two are at the Yad Vashem in Israel, one is at the US Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C., and one privately owned list was unsuccessfully auctioned off via eBay in 2013. The movie refers to the first two lists created in 1944, otherwise known as “The Lists of Life.” The five subsequent lists were updates to the first two versions, which included the names of more than 1000 Jews who Schindler saved by recruiting them to work in his factory. The late Bruno Ganz, a Swiss actor who portrayed Adolf Hitler in the 2004 German-language film der Untergang (Downfall). Photo: Courtesy of Maximillian Buhn. The best historical film ever made arguably is the German-language der Untergang (Downfall), which was released in 2004. It depicts the last few days of Hitler’s life as the Nazi dictator was holed up in the Fuhrerbunker near his Chancellery, ordering around largely nonexistent German armies from conference room maps and bewailing his fate at the hands of subordinates (namely, Goering and Himmler) whom he perceived as betraying him. The feat of accurately depicting Hitler and the events leading up to his suicide had been attempted by other actors, notably by Sir Alec Guiness in in the British and Italian-made movie Hitler: The Last Ten Days (1973) and by Sir Anthony Hopkins, in The Bunker (1981), a made-for-television film. Despite the talents of these gifted actors, neither of them arguably came close to depicting Hitler in all of his psychological complexity and genius as the late Bruno Ganz, a Swiss actor, whose German language fluency and mastery of Hitler’s distinctly guttural Austrian accent added a extra layer of authenticity to the film. Much of the script was based on the memoirs of Traudl Junge, who was with Hitler until the end and who, along with other survivors, attested to the complicated nature of Hitler’s personality. Joachim Fest’s Hitler’s Bunker also served as one of the primary texts for the script. All of this complexity was portrayed - in the view of the remaining survivors of his inner circle, brilliantly and convincingly - by Ganz. In fact, several of Ganz’s scenes in the the film are apparently so searing and memorable, notably the one in which he is informed by Gens. Jodl, Krebs and Burgdorf that there is no hope of Gen. Steiner’s relieving Berlin from the Soviet onslaught, that they have sparked scores of parodies. Ganz’s also does a masterful job depicting all of Hitler’s changing moods in the cloistered environs of the Fuhrerbunker: his courtly manner around Junge and his other secretaries, his appalling capacity for self-pity and assigning blame, his occasionally remarkable insouciance in the face of the utter calamity that awaited him and his social order, and his perfervid vindictiveness, particularly his obsession with hunting down and executing his soon-to-be brother-in-law, S.S. Gruppenfuhrer Hermann Fegelein, whose awareness of the futility of further resistance had led him to flee the bunker. Several other scenes in the film expertly portray the utter futility of the struggle, for example, Hitler’s realization on the morning of his birthday, April 20th, that the bunker is under attack by Soviet artillery, which underscores that the Soviets have moved within with striking of the Wilhelmstrasse (the Government District). One also gets an impression of the cultic devotion to Hitler and to Nazi ideology - Magda Goebbels cyanide poisoning of her 6 children on the basis that life simply wouldn’t be fit to live in a post-Nationalist Socialist Germany, and, following final smokes and dousing of cigarettes, the grim suicides of Krebs and Burgdorf, virtually the last personnel left in the bunker. Also memorable is Hitler’s last conference with his Minister of Armaments, Albert Speer, perhaps the only figure in the Third Reich who could lay a convincing claim to having forged a genuine friendship with Hitler. Having read significantly about this final encounter, I’m convinced that no other depiction comes close to conveying Hitler’s sense of futility and resignation as the end approached. Like most historical films, der Untergang occasionally departs from fact. One notable departure involved the fate of Junge, one of the primary focuses the film. Far from eluding the Soviets with the aid of Peter Kranz, a Hitler Youth defector, Junge actually suffered brutal treatment by Soviet troops and ultimately sought the protection of a Soviet colonel in the weeks following the German surrender. All in all, though, the film serves up an altogether remarkable depiction of the events leading up to the fall of the Third Reich at the hands of deeply enraged, marauding Soviet troops in May, 1945.

That depends on what you mean by ‘best’ - the most accurate, the best story, acting or photography? Let’s try and roll that into one and see what we get and in no particular order:- Lawrence of Arabia - stunning to look at, sweeping historical perspective, acting performances of a lifetime and the long shot entry of Omar Sharif which stays with you oh.. only forever. Does it teach you anything about a complicated and world changing sequence of events? I would suggest yes and the double dealing politicians who you can never trust.Last of the Mohicans - every historical epic post 1962 carries the legacy of David Lean (Lawrence’s director) and this is no exception. Although very compressed and feeling like an hour plus was cut, the film looks like the story it tells. Daniel Day Lewis, whatever you may feel about his method acting, simply is Hawkeye and looks like he was born with a musket in his hand. Historically it was a side show of a side show so as to its accuracy you have to accept its a story. The Hawkeye speech hinting about future independence might have been better aimed at the cost of the campaign - ‘don't think we’re paying for all this Redcoats’.Waterloo - OK Rod Steiger’s Napoleon chews the scenery but the large battle scenes pre CGI are unmatched. The Charge of the Scots Greys is so impressive you could actually have been there and the helicopter shots were then stunning and original. The British infantry forming squares to repell the French cavalry again represent the most accurate yet on film. Plummer is better than good as Wellington and large parts of the script are faithfully recorded speeches from the day.That is my ‘best’ three, others that come to mind include Dunkirk, The Charge of the Light Brigade, Barry Lyndon and The Battle of Britain. Just don't mention Braveheart.

There are two ways to judge the best Historical movies. Either the movie is the best at conveying a “you-are-there” historical event, or the historical event is so well-written, so entertaining, that you don’t mind the dramatic license taken. So for best historical movies, I would gather “United 93” probably takes the cake, in terms of slavish attention to mundane detail (unseen by me; still not ready after all these years). I suppose “Jackie” hoped to qualify as well. Going back to centuries ago, I believe that “Gettysburg” and “Gods and Generals” also were exquisitely, painstakingly detailed (even if the latter film had no dramatic arc to keep the story focused). Going back even further, I suspect that “The Passion of the Christ” had elements that were extremely historical, in that it was delivered in the Aramaic tongue, and the gore was probably accurate for the torture that occurred. However, since it was largely based on the visions of a later Saint, it doesn’t count. But for best-written, sparkling dialogue historical films, I would definitely say “A Man For All Seasons” is most likely tops. But it may be dethroned by the upcoming “Hamilton” musical, whenever that is released.

I don’t know if it was the best movie. That’s so subjective. But one of my favorites is Eight Men Out. It tells the story of one of the greatest teams that ever played baseball - the 1919 Chicago White Sox. They were far and away expected to win the World Series that year. The problem was the owner was tight with his money and since this was long before there was a baseball union he took advantage of the players at every opportunity. Gambling concerns took advantage and offered some of the players money to throw the series. In the end the story came out and several players were banned for life including those who didn’t get what they were promised and played some of the best baseball of their lives and a few who didn’t accept any money and went out every game trying to win. It’s a well told story with some great performances particularly from John Cusack, Gordon Clapp, David Strathairn, and D.B. Sweeney as “Shoeless” Joe Jackson.

I just want to list a few movies that weren’t just very good, but also very important in film history. I want to start with the 1967 Bonnie and Clyde, which began the trend towards film “realism” that took hold in the 1970s. Movies such as Little Big Man, Dirty Harry, and MASH all owe a debt to Bonnie and Clyde. Next two together, Alien (1979) and Terminator (1984), that totally redefined the sci fi and horror genre. Alien had great suspense and introduced graphic violence, while Terminator introduced the body count to genre films, most notably ridiculed by Robert Rodriguez in From Dusk Til Dawn. Many people won’t like this next selection, but our post-modern outlook on historical dramas can largely be traced to Cleopatra (1964). The much more detailed psychology found in historical dramas ever since can be largely traced to Cleopatra. Finally, of course Star Wars (1977) started our modern special effects in genre films, and really was the original (and never exceeded) blockbuster.

The film that has generally been considered the best of all time for decades is Citizen Kane, written and directed by Orson Welles. More recently, however, international film critics have moved Alfred Hitchcock’s Vertigo to the #1 position. Other films that are often hailed as being among the 10 best films of all time, including by the American Film Institute, include Casablanca, The Godfather, Lawrence of Arabia, The Graduate, On the Waterfront, and Schindler’s List. The all-time classics Sunset Boulevard and It’s A Wonderful Life are also often listed as among the greatest films of all time, and they are certainly among the most beloved. I would add Doctor Zhivago and Witness for the Prosecution to my personal list. If you really want a tutorial, download the AFI 100 Best Best Films of All Time, watch all of them, and make up your own mind. Great films are also highly personal experiences and choices.

O’Toole, Hepburn, Hopkins, Dalton. The movie combines drama, tragedy, razor sharp comedy, great performances and the best dialogue ever spoken on the screen. Mr. Harvey, then living in East Hampton, enthralled us with tales of his days working at the Boulting Brothers London studio. Just to pick one would be unfair to so many history films. But it I personally had to pick one film based on some history it would undoubtedly be “The Pianist” for not just because it won many awards or because critics called it a masterpiece because critic reviews font influence me, but it was because at the end of all it was an act of humanity and a beautiful piece of music, that stayed with me for a long time. The producing design, music, acting and narative was impeccable and the way our Pianist maneuvers his life through the german soldiers to protect any Jewish that he can was heart touching. When the film open as the german tops barge in the country inside all people's houses and the way they start harassing people was just inhuman to watch. And we realise that even out protagonist couldn't do anything all he could do was stare with those unhelpful eyes. Trying not to spoil the climax when the german soldier asks him to play the piano for him, a hungry Adrian Brody with weak arms and legs walks towards the piano imagining that his life depends on this music, hoping that he doesn't flounder. But the moment his fingers touch the piano the artist inside him takes over and he plays the music not caring about the war, his life or even the fate of Jewish people. And seeing this passion from the pianist the “human” inside the german soldier awakens and decides to protect him. all it took was one beautiful piece of music amidst the sounds of tanks and bullets to put an end to everything. But the beauty of how the scene was constructed gives me goosebumps even writing it. I won't give you the ending because you have to watch it for yourself. THE PIANIST Happy new year cheers……
